key_points: A bombing and shooting outside Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul killed 13 U.S. service members and more than 150 Afghan civilians.
The Islamic State Khorasan (ISIS-K) claimed responsibility for the Kabul airport attack.
The U.S. completed its withdrawal from Afghanistan, marking the end of a 20-year war.
ISIS-K is a regional affiliate of the Islamic State and a rival of the Taliban, aiming to establish a caliphate in the historical region of Khorasan.
ISIS-K was founded by former members of the Pakistani Taliban, the Afghan Taliban, and others, and seeks to establish an Islamic government.
The group is known for its extreme views, especially regarding women and ethnic minorities, and has conducted deadly attacks against civilians.
President Biden vowed retaliation against ISIS-K for the Kabul airport attack; the U.S. subsequently carried out drone strikes killing top ISIS-K members.
The rivalry between the Taliban and ISIS-K means that the former is unlikely to offer safe haven to ISIS-K members.
Concerns remain about how the Taliban will police ISIS-K and the potential for disruptions in a Taliban-controlled Afghanistan.
America's exit from Afghanistan could benefit ISIS-K, despite the group's recent territorial and leadership losses.
spokespersons: Navy Capt. Bill Urban (U.S. Central Command spokesman)
